question: You  have  said  that,  /  as  he  took  money  from  you  many times, / he owes you / ﬁve thousand rupees all together.

options.D: as he took money from you many times

solution.correct_answer: B. ﬁve thousand rupees all together
solution.explanation: ﬁve thousand rupees all together ‘All together’ must be replaced with ‘altogether’, which means totally. Hence, ‘ﬁve thousand rupees altogether’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select the option that contains an error; I  stayed  in  my hometown  with  my parents  on  the pandemic.

solution.explanation: on ‘On’ is used to indicate a speciﬁc occasion or day. ‘During’ is used to indicate a speciﬁc period of time. Similarly, ‘pandemic’ is a speciﬁc period of time. Hence, ‘during’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: In  August,  she  will  be  /  enjoying  /  all  the  fruits  her grandmother / will plant last January.

solution.explanation: will plant last January The phrase ‘last January’ indicates the use of simple past tense. ‘Will plant’ must be replaced with the past form ‘planted’. Hence, ‘planted last January’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  compensation  that  the  [A]  /  Government  agreed  to provide  to  [B]  /  the  dependents  of  the  [C]  /  train  accident  is  fairly less [D].

solution.explanation: D- train accident is fairly less ‘Less’ must be replaced with ‘low’ as there is no comparison in this sentence. Hence, ‘train accident is fairly low’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: (a)The more it rains,/(b) worse/(c) the roads become/(d) No error

solution.explanation: worse ‘Worse’ must be replaced with ‘the worse’. When change in one thing causes the change in the other and two comparative degrees are used to indicate this relationship, it is called successive comparison. Article ‘the’ is used before both the comparative degrees. Hence, ‘the worse’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Mr  Unkerton  glanced  /  to  the  inspector,  /  who  merely snorted / and looked at the ceiling.

solution.explanation: to the inspector ‘To’ must be replaced with ‘at’ as we use ‘at’ with ‘glance’ for a person. Hence, ‘at the inspector’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: She  spotted  the  novel  [A]  /  and  shouted,  "Here  the  book  lies [B] / that we were searching for[C] / all around."[D]

solution.explanation: B - and shouted, “Here the book lies ‘That’ is a relative pronoun which takes a noun or pronoun as its antecedent. In the given sentence, ‘the book’ is the antecedent, which will be used before ‘that’. Hence, and shouted, “Here lies the book is the most appropriate answer.

question: Raghu  did  not  get  the  job  /  because  he  did  not  have  / experience enough for the post.

options.C: Raghu did not get the job

solution.explanation: experience enough for the post ‘Enough’ is an adjective which describes the noun ‘experience’, therefore ‘enough’ will be used before ‘experience’. Hence, ‘enough experience for the job’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I  will  have  been  studying  English  for  three  years  by  the  end  of this course. SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)

options.A: I had been studying English for three years by the end of this
options.B: I have been studying English for three years by the end of this
options.C: I will have been studying English for three years by the end of
options.D: I was studying English for three years by the end of this

solution.correct_answer: C. I will have been studying English for three years by the end of
solution.explanation: I will have been studying English for three years by the end of this course.

question: The police are searching about the missing jewellery. SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: about ‘For’ is the ﬁxed preposition used after the verb ‘search’. Hence, ‘for’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: John is really / good in/ playing/ the piano. SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: good in The structure ‘good + at + V ing ’ is used to show that you are very skilful and clever at doing something. Hence, ‘good at’ is the most appropriate answer. SSC CHSL 2024 Tier - 2

question: The  Supreme  Court  set  away  /  the  verdict  of  the  High Court / and agreed to hear the plea / of the complainant. SSC CHSL Tier II  (18/11/2024)

options.C: and agreed to hear the plea
options.d: the verdict of the High Court

solution.explanation: The Supreme Court set away ‘Set away’ must be replaced with ‘set aside’. The phrasal verb ‘set aside’ means to deprive of legal effect because it has been proved wrong. The given sentence states that the Supreme Court set aside the verdict of the High Court. Hence, ‘The Supreme Court set aside’ is the most appropriate answer. SSC MTS 2024 Tier - 1

question: Mrs  Premlatha  asked  /  Malini  to  hand  down  /  all  the  / payment slips. SSC MTS 30/09/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Malini to hand down ‘Hand down’ must be replaced with ‘hand out’. The phrasal verb ‘hand out’ means to give a slip or document to someone. The given sentence talks about giving all the payment slips. Hence, ‘Malini to hand out’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: She is / as more intelligent as / her brothers  are. SSC MTS 01/10/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: as more intelligent as ‘As + adjective/adverb + as’ is a comparative structure in which the adjective or the adverb is always in the positive degree. Therefore, ‘more’ will be replaced with ‘much’. Hence, ‘as much intelligent as’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He  is  waiting  /  at  airport  to  receive  /  Mr  Smith,  who  is  / coming from South Africa. SSC MTS 07/10/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: at airport to receive Article ‘the’ is used to refer to a speciﬁc or particular noun. ‘Airport’ given in the sentence is speciﬁc as the person is waiting there. Hence, ‘at the airport to receive’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I  hope  that  /  yesterday's  lunch  /  at  Rahul's  place  /  was  at your liking. SSC MTS 08/10/2024 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: was at your liking “To one’s liking” is the correct phrase, which means appealable or enjoyable to someone. Therefore, ‘at your liking’ must be replaced with ‘to your liking’. Hence, ‘was to your liking’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: She forbade / him not / to enter that / room. SSC MTS 09/10/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: him not ‘Not’ must be removed from this sentence. ‘Forbade’ is the past form of ‘forbid’, which means to not allow someone to do something. The use of ‘not’ with ‘forbade’ is superﬂuous. Hence, ‘forbade him to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He  climbed  of  /  the  steep  mountain  trail,  /  his  backpack heavy / with supplies for the journey. SSC MTS 14/10/2024 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: He climbed of ‘Climbed of’ must be replaced with ‘climbed up’. ‘Up’ is used to indicate upwards movement. Hence, ‘he climbed up’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Sam  and  Teena  /  had  wondering  /  what  to  do  this weekend. SSC MTS 15/10/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: had wondering The given sentence is an example of present continuous tense and the subject ‘Sam and Teena’ is plural. ‘Plural Subject + are + V ing ’ is the correct grammatical structure for it. Hence, ‘are

question: You  know  that  I  am  fond  of  reading  /  and  also  that  all books  are  my  favourite  /  but  you  don’t  know  that  this  is  one  of  / my favourite book. SSC MTS 16/10/2024 (Morning)

options.A: but you don’t know that this is one of
options.B: and also that all books are my favourite
options.D: You know that I am fond of reading

solution.explanation: my favourite book ‘One of + plural noun’ is the correct grammatical structure. Therefore, the plural noun ‘books’ will be used. Hence, ‘my favourite books’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select the sentence that has a grammatical error. SSC MTS 16/10/2024 (Evening)

options.A: This is a very diﬃcult task to accomplish.
options.B: A young boy offered her his seat.
options.C: I wish I had eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life.
options.D: I have a lot of work to complete.

solution.correct_answer: C. I wish I had eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life.
solution.explanation: I wish I had eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life. Article ‘an’ will be used before the noun ‘eraser’ as it starts with a vowel sound. Hence, the correct sentence is- ‘I wish I had an eraser to erase all the mistakes in my life.’

question: In  addition  with  /  the  existing  crisis  in  economy,  /  the  rise of hunger index / is another cause of worry. SSC MTS 17/10/2024 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: in addition with ‘In addition to’ is the correct phrase. Hence, ‘in addition to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select the sentence that has a grammatical error. SSC MTS 18/10/2024 (Evening)

options.A: She usually walks her dog in the park every morning.
options.B: The train leaves the station at 8:00 a.m. every day.
options.C: They play chess together on weekends.

solution.correct_answer: D. He don't like spicy food.
solution.explanation: He don’t like spicy food. ‘The given sentence is in the simple present tense and ‘Singular Subject(He) + does + not + V 1 ’’ is the correct grammatical structure for it. Hence, the correct sentence is- ‘He doesn’t like spicy food.’

question: Select the grammatically correct sentence. SSC MTS 21/10/2024 (Afternoon)

options.A: An intricate dance of neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft
options.B: An intricate dance of neurotransmitters in a synaptic cleft
options.C: The intricate dance of neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft
options.D: The intricate dance of neurotransmitters in a synaptic cleft

solution.correct_answer: C. The intricate dance of neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft
solution.explanation: The intricate dance of neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft plays a crucial role in neural communication. ‘Dance’ and ‘cleft’ mentioned in the sentence are speciﬁc and we generally use the deﬁnite article ‘the’ before a speciﬁc or particular noun. The noun ‘role’ is not speciﬁc and we generally use an indeﬁnite article before a non-speciﬁc noun. The word ‘crucial’ starts with a consonant sound, therefore, article ‘a’ will be used before it. Hence, the sentence given in option (c) is correct.

question: He  will  have  to  /  knuckle  up  really  seriously,  /  if  he  wants to / crack the upcoming deal. SSC MTS 21/10/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: knuckle up really seriously ‘Knuckle up’ must be replaced with ‘knuckle down’. The phrasal verb ‘knuckle down’ means to put in serious effort. The given sentence states that he will have to knuckle down really seriously if he wants to crack the upcoming deal. Hence, ‘knuckle down really seriously’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select  the  grammatically  correct  sentence  from  the  given options. SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (Afternoon)

options.A: A lot of books and notes place in order look most
options.B: A lot of books and notes placed in order look fascinating.
options.C: A lot of books and notes placed on order looks most
options.D: A lot of book and notes placed in order looks most

solution.correct_answer: B. A lot of books and notes placed in order look fascinating.
solution.explanation: A lot of books and notes placed in order look fascinating. ‘A lot of books and notes’ is a plural subject that will take ‘look’ as a plural verb. The phrase ‘in order’ means arranged systematically. We can not use the superlative degree of ‘fascinating’ as there is no comparison with any other thing. Hence, the sentence given in option (b) is grammatically correct.

question: He  missed  the  college  bus  /  because  he  woke  up  / unpardonably lately in the morning. SSC MTS 28/10/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: unpardonably lately in the morning ‘Lately’ must be replaced with ‘late’. ‘Late’ means after the usual or expected time. ‘Lately’ means in the recent times. The given sentence is talking about waking up after the expected time in the morning. Hence, ‘unpardonably late in the morning’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: After  the  match,  /  the  stadium  was  the  messiest  /  it’s  ever been. SSC MTS 30/10/2024 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Gita got onto / the book / she was reading /  this morning. SSC MTS 30/10/2024 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Gita got onto ‘Got onto’ must be replaced with 'got into'. The phrasal verb ‘got into’ means became interested in a subject or activity. The given sentence talks about the interest of Gita in the book she was reading. Hence, ‘Gita got into’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Although  experts  are  worried  /  that  retail  inﬂation  is  rising / at a steep rate, / the crisis will soon blow away. SSC MTS 04/11/2024 (Morning)

options.C: the crisis will soon blow away

solution.correct_answer: C. the crisis will soon blow away
solution.explanation: the crisis will soon blow away ‘Blow away’ must be replaced with ‘blow over’. The phrasal verb ‘blow over’ means to pass by or to end. The given sentence states that the crisis will soon end. Hence, ‘the crisis will soon blow over’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select  the  option  that  has  an  error  in  the  use  of  present tense. SSC MTS 05/11/2024 (Afternoon)

options.A: The painter is painting the wall right now.
options.B: The mother cooks delicious food for her children.
options.C: I am observing your mischievous activities for half an hour.
options.D: I have performed all my duties with utmost sincerity.

solution.correct_answer: C. I am observing your mischievous activities for half an hour.
solution.explanation: I am observing your mischievous activities for half an hour. Present perfect continuous tense will be used in this sentence as a ﬁxed period of time is mentioned with the preposition ‘for’. Therefore, ‘am observing’ must be replaced with ‘have been observing’. Hence, the correct sentence is - ‘I have been observing your mischievous activities for half an hour.’

question: My  mother  is  51  years  old,  /  and  my  uncle  is  48  years  old. / So my mother is old than my uncle. SSC MTS 11/11/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.B: and my uncle is 48 years old.
options.C: So my mother is old than my uncle

solution.correct_answer: C. So my mother is old than my uncle
solution.explanation: So my mother is old than my uncle ‘Old’ must be replaced with the comparative degree ‘older’ as the given sentence compares the age of mother and uncle. Hence, ‘So my mother is older than my uncle’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: My  sister  is  allergic  with  peanuts,  so  be  cautious  when preparing her meal SSC MTS 11/11/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: allergic with peanuts ‘To’ is the ﬁxed preposition used after the adjective ‘allergic’. Hence, ‘allergic to peanuts’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select the sentence that has a grammatical error. SSC MTS 11/11/2024 (Evening)

options.A: They have an information about the event.
options.B: The cat is sleeping on a mat.
options.C: She is an artist at a local gallery.
options.D: Can you bring me the keys to the car?

solution.correct_answer: A. They have an information about the event.
solution.explanation: They have an information about the event. ‘Information’ is an uncountable noun and we generally do not use indeﬁnite articles (a/an) with uncountable nouns. Therefore, ‘an’ will be removed. Hence, the correct sentence is- ‘They have information about the event.’

question: Whenever  she  is  coming  /  here,  she  brings  /  many  gifts  for everyone. SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Whenever she is coming ‘Whenever’ is used when one action is always followed by another action. Simple present tense is used with ‘whenever’. ‘She’ is a singular subject that will take ‘comes’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘Whenever she comes’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select  the  grammatically  correct  sentence  from  the  given options. SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (Evening)

options.A: She was not allowed to enter the hotel as her clothes was
options.B: She was not allow to enter the hotel as her clothes were dirty.
options.C: She was not allowed to enter the hotel as her clothes were
options.D: She was not allowed to enter the hotel as her clothes were

solution.correct_answer: D. She was not allowed to enter the hotel as her clothes were
solution.explanation: She was not allowed to enter the hotel as her clothes were dirty. ‘Singular Subject + was + V 3 ’ is the correct passive structure for simple past tense. ‘Clothes’ is a plural subject that will take ‘were’ as a plural verb. Hence, the sentence given in option (d) is correct.

question: My  aunt  came  from  Switzerland  by  the  ﬂight  which  was landing at 5:00 a.m. yesterday. SSC MTS 13/11/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Switzerland by the We generally do not use article ‘the’ after ‘by’ when we mention the means of transport such as bus, train, bike, car, ﬂight, etc. Therefore, article ‘the’ will be removed. Hence, ‘Switzerland by’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: (1) We  knocked  across/(2)  early  on  Saturday/(3)  to  enjoy/(4) the beautiful weather.

solution.explanation: We knocked across ‘Knocked across’ must be replaced with the phrasal verb ‘knocked off’. ‘Knock off’ means to stop work. The given sentence states that we stopped work early on Saturday to enjoy the beautiful weather. Hence, ‘We knocked off’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He  bought  strange  vintage  car  on  auction  from  the customs department. SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: strange vintage car We generally use an indeﬁnite article (a/an) before a non-speciﬁc noun. In the given sentence, the word ‘strange’ starts with a consonant sound. Therefore, article ‘a’ will be used. Hence, ‘a strange vintage car’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I  thought  of  this  idea  /  just  when  you  called  /  me yesterday. SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Meenu looks / much better / today. SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Mr  Abhilash  and  his  family  /  have  received  /  no informations / about the incident. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: no informations ‘Informations’ must be replaced with ‘information’ as ‘information’ is an uncountable noun and its plural cannot be formed. Hence, 'no information' is the most appropriate answer.

question: Every  students  in  the  hostel  decided  to  travel  to  Delhi  to witness the Republic Day parade. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Every students in the hostel ‘Everyone/each/ every/ nothing/ everything/ anything/ either/ neither’ represents a singular noun. Therefore, ‘students’ must be replaced with the singular noun ‘student’. Hence, ‘Every student in the hostel’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: By  this  time  next  year  /  I  will  had  graduated  from  college  / and starting my ﬁrst job / in the ﬁeld of marketing. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.D: I will had graduated from college

solution.explanation: I will had graduated from college ‘Subject + will have + V 3 ’ is the correct grammatical structure for a sentence which is in the future perfect tense. Therefore, ‘will had’ must be replaced with ‘will have’. Hence, ‘I will have graduated from college’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I are dancing with my husband at my sister’s  wedding. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: I are dancing ‘Am’ is the correct helping verb to use with ‘I’ in present continuous tense. Hence, ‘I am dancing’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: After  the  concert  was  over,  /  they  go  to  a  restaurant,  /  had dinner together / and talked until midnight. SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. they go to a restaurant,
solution.explanation: they go to a restaurant,

question: Renewable  energy  /  sources  like  solar  and  wind  power  / will  replaced  traditional  fossil  fuels  /  and  help  reduce  carbon emissions. SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)

options.D: sources like solar and wind power

solution.correct_answer: C. will replaced traditional fossil fuels
solution.explanation: will replaced traditional fossil fuels ‘Modal verbs’ are auxiliary verbs(also called helping verbs) like can, will, could, shall, must, would, might, and should. However, after a modal verb, we generally use the ﬁrst form of the verb (V 1 ). Hence, ‘will replace(V 1 ) traditional fossil fuels’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: No  other  place  in  this  country  is  so  better  as  Gulmarg, Kashmir. SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: so better as Positive degree adjective is used in the structure ‘as…as’ or ‘so…as’ to make a comparison. Therefore, ‘better’ must be replaced with ‘good’. Hence, ‘so good as’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Our  family  is  planning  /  a  trip  to  Europe  next  summer  / where  we  should  visit  several  famous  /  landmarks  and  enjoy local cuisine. SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.A: where we should visit several famous
options.D: a trip to Europe next summer

solution.correct_answer: A. where we should visit several famous
solution.explanation: where we should visit several famous ‘Should’ must be replaced with ‘will’ as the action of visiting several famous landmarks will happen in the future (next summer). Hence, ‘where we will visit several famous’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: It is he who work for the company for more than  a decade. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: who work ‘Who work’ must be replaced with ‘who has been working’ as we use the perfect continuous tense with ‘for/since’ to indicate time period. Hence, ‘who has been working’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  windows  /  violent  banged  /  during  the  /  storm yesterday. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: violent banged ‘Violent’ must be replaced with ‘violently’ as the given sentence needs an adverb to modify the verb ‘banged’. Hence, ‘violently banged’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Neither my brother nor my brothers-in-law /  attended the meeting / as his health is not more good. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.A: Neither my brother nor my brothers-in-law
options.D: as his health is not more good

solution.correct_answer: D. as his health is not more good
solution.explanation: as his health is not more good ‘More’ must be removed as we use comparative degree adjective to make a comparison but there is no comparison between the health of two people. The ﬁrst part of the sentence is in the past tense, so the verb in the second clause will also be in the past tense(V 2 ). Hence, ‘as his health was not good’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Rahul thinks he is as smarter as his friends in the class. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. he is as smarter as
solution.explanation: he is as smarter as ‘As + adjective/adverb + as’ is a comparative structure in which we always use positive degree. Therefore, ‘smarter’ must be replaced with ‘smart’. Hence, ‘he is as smart as’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Solutions  to  the  country’s  interior  problems  are  still  a  long way away. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: the country’s interior The correct word to use in this sentence is ‘internal’, not ‘interior’. ‘Internal’ means occurring inside a country. Hence, the country’s internal is the most appropriate answer.

question: They secret / decided / to leave / the town. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: They secret The given sentence needs an adverb ‘secretly’ to modify the verb ‘decided’, not the noun ‘secret’. Hence, ‘They secretly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He ran quick to catch the bus. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: quickly The given sentence needs an adverb ‘quickly’ to modify the verb ‘ran’, not the adjective ‘quick’. Hence, ‘quickly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Mrs  Sreelakshmi’s  /  musical  intelligence  /  is  superior  than / Mrs Suma’s. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: is superior than There are some words that take the preposition ‘to’ after them. For example:- superior to, inferior to, prior to, elder to, junior to, senior to, etc. Hence ‘is superior to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  employees  were  comfortable  /  with  me  and  they talked  about  /  their  problems  since  /  I  has  worked  there  as  a manager. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.A: I has worked there as a manager.
options.B: with me and they talked about

solution.correct_answer: A. I has worked there as a manager.
solution.explanation: I has worked there as a manager. The given sentence is in the past tense, so it must have the verb of past tense. ‘Had’ will be used instead of ‘has’. Hence, ‘I had worked there as a manager’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  following  sentence  has  been  divided  into  four segments.  Identify  the  segment  that  contains  an  adverbial usage error. Mr. Arun / will pay dear / for his / ﬁnancial mistake. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: will pay dear The given sentence needs an adverb ‘dearly’ to modify the verb ‘pay’, not the adjective ‘dear’. Hence, ‘will pay dearly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: My brother received / his MBA degree into /  the university last year. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: his MBA degree into ‘Into’ must be replaced with 'from' as we use ‘from’ to indicate the source of something. Hence, ‘his MBA degree from’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He  replied  /  in  a  dry  tone,  /  “Ouch!  I  will  not  work  /  for  you anymore.” SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: ''Ouch! I will not work ‘Ouch!’ is used to express pain. However, in the given sentence, the speaker replied in a dry tone. So, the correct interjection to use is ‘Ugh!’. Hence, ‘Ugh! I will not work for you anymore’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Mr.  Surya  /  have  no  interior  /  motive  in  offering  /  you support. SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: have no interior ‘Have no interior’ must be replaced with ‘has no ulterior’. ‘Mr. Surya’ is a singular subject that will take ‘has’ as a singular verb. Also, the correct word to use here is ‘ulterior’. ‘Ulterior motive’ means a secret reason for doing something. Hence, ‘has no ulterior’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: By  the  end  of  /  this  month,  he  /  will  been  working  /  for  ﬁve years. SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: will been working ‘Will been’ must be replaced with ‘will have been’. Future perfect continuous tense (will have been + V ing ) is used to talk about the duration of an action that has happened until some point in the future and will still be happening. Hence, ‘will have been working’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I  have  the  hundred  reasons  to  not  attend  the  meeting tomorrow. SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.correct_answer: A. I have the hundred reasons
solution.explanation: I have the hundred reasons The reasons given in the sentence are not speciﬁc and we use indeﬁnite article for a non-speciﬁc noun. Article ‘a’ will be used as the word ‘hundred’ begins with a consonant sound. Hence, ‘I have a hundred reasons’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: After  I  retire,  I  started  a  second  career  /  as  a  writer  and published  several  books  /  which  allowed  me  to  share  my  stories / and insights with a wider audience. SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.A: and insights with a wider audience
options.B: After I retire, I started a second career
options.C: as a writer and published several books
options.D: which allowed me to share my stories

solution.correct_answer: B. After I retire, I started a second career
solution.explanation: After I retire, I started a second career If two actions took place in the past then the 1st action must be in the Past perfect tense(Had + V 3 ) and the 2nd action must be in the Simple Past tense(V 2 ). However, the V 3 form of ‘retire’ is ‘retired’. Hence, ‘After I had retired (V 3 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Parts  of  the  given  sentence  have  been  underlined.  Identify the part that has an error. Select 'No error' if there is no error. Although  the  team  had  trained  diligently  for  months  ,  they  had still overwhelmed  by the opponent's unexpected tactics.

solution.explanation: had still overwhelmed ‘Had’ must be replaced with ‘were’ as the given sentence is an example of a passive voice of simple past tense and ‘Plural subject (they) + were + V 3 ’ is the correct grammatical structure for it. Hence, ‘were still overwhelmed(V 3 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Due  to  the  pandemic,  /  the  prices  of  /  medicines  increased / every day since / last December.

solution.explanation: medicines increased We use present continuous tense with ‘for/since’ to show that something has been happening for a period of time. ‘Plural subject (prices) + have been + V ing ’ is the correct grammatical structure for it. Hence, ‘medicines have been increasing’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  following  sentence  has  been  divided  into  four segments.  Identify  the  segment  in  which  the  article  has  been used INCORRECTLY. UNESCO  works  to  /  strengthen  an  intellectual  /  and  moral solidarity / of humankind. SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: strengthen an intellectual Indeﬁnite article ‘a/an’ is not used for an abstract noun(solidarity). The deﬁnite article ‘the’ is used before a speciﬁc or particular noun. The given sentence is referring to a speciﬁc type of solidarity. Hence, ‘strengthen the intellectual and

question: Dr.  Sinha  has  /  brought  about  a  new  /  book  on  social  / impact of child labour. SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: brought about a new ‘Brought out’ is the correct phrasal verb here, which means ‘published’. The given sentence is talking about publishing a new book. Hence, ‘brought out a new’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select the sentence that has a grammatical error. SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.A: It is said that Joseph was not ready to go to war.
options.B: Karl Marx was a renowned social scientist.
options.C: Indian force are known for their loyalty and integrity.
options.D: It is impossible to wake Christine up in the morning.

solution.correct_answer: C. Indian force are known for their loyalty and integrity.
solution.explanation: Indian force are known for their loyalty and integrity. ‘Forces’ will be used instead of ‘force’ according to the plural verb ‘are’ and the plural adjective ‘their’. Hence, the correct sentence is: “Indian forces are known for their loyalty and integrity.”

question: Brr, the city view from the Eiffel Tower is  amazing ! SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Brr An interjection is a word or phrase used to express a sudden feeling. ‘Brr’ is used to express the sensation of cold. ‘Wow’ is used to express a sudden feeling of amazement. Hence, ‘Wow’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Having  known  that  /  the  train  was  already  on  the  platform, / they ran fastly / to catch it. SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.C: the train was already on the platform

solution.explanation: they ran fastly ‘Fast’ is already an adverb. The word ‘fastly’ does not exist. Hence, ‘they ran fast’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select  the  option  that  spots  the  error  in  the  use  of preposition in the given sentence. Deepa  and  Seema  are  both  good  with  running,  but  Deepa  is  also good  at  catching  the  ball  and  throwing  it  to  the  right  corner  in time. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: good with running Preposition ‘at’ is used to show that someone is good at doing something. ‘Good + at + V ing ’ is the correct structure. Hence, ‘good at running’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: People  admired  him,  for  /  he  lived  by  the  same  principals  / that he preached. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.C: he lived by the same principals

solution.correct_answer: C. he lived by the same principals
solution.explanation: he lived by the same principals ‘Principals’ must be replaced with ‘principles’ as the given sentence talks about a kind of belief or idea that guides you. Hence, ‘he lived by the same principles’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: We  were  on  the  way/  to  the  party;/  suddenly,  there/  will  a heavy downpour. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: will a heavy downpour. The given sentence is in the past tense, not in the future tense, so it must have the verb in the past form ‘was’, . Hence, ‘was a heavy downpour’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He never talks / for anybody. / He is alone  / all day. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: for anybody ‘To’ is used to denote the person to whom someone is talking. Hence, ‘to anybody’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  police  told  the  agitators  to  back  in,  else  they  would lathi-charge. SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.correct_answer: C. the agitators to back in
solution.explanation: the agitators to back in ‘Back out’ is the correct phrasal verb to use here. ‘Back out’ means to withdraw or decide not to do something that was planned to do. Hence, ‘the agitators to back out’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: We  took  dinner  in  a  Chinese  restaurant  and  were  amazed to see the interior of a restaurant. SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: the interior of a restaurant Article ‘the’ is used when we refer to the same noun again because it becomes speciﬁc. Hence, ‘the interior of the restaurant’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Mr Ali’s shop / is further to / the hospital. SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.correct_answer: A. is further to  (b) No error  (c) Mr. Ali’s shop  (d) the hospital.
solution.explanation: is further to ‘Farther than’ will be used instead of ‘further to’. ‘Further’ is used for metaphorical distance where ‘farther’ is used for physical distance. The given sentence is talking about the physical distance between Mr. Ali’s shop and the hospital. Hence, ‘farther than’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Select  the  option  that  corrects  the  error  in  the  given sentence. She sings good. SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: well The given sentence needs an adverb(well) to modify the verb (sings) and not an adjective(good). Hence, ‘Rahul sings well’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: In some countries, you are not able to drink  until you are 21 SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: able to drink The correct word to use here is ‘allowed’ instead of ‘able’. The given sentence states that you are not allowed to drink until you are 21. Hence, ‘allowed to drink’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Two  of  the  world’s  /  best  forwards  /  has  played  alongside / David Beckham. SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: has played alongside According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a plural subject always takes a plural verb. In the given sentence, ‘Two of the world’s best forwards’ is a plural subject that will take ‘have’ as a plural verb. Hence, ‘have played alongside’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Ourselves should not boast of one’s knowledge. SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Ourselves ‘Ourselves’ must be replaced with 'We' as we use a subjective case pronoun (I/we/you) as the subject of a sentence. Hence, 'We' is the most appropriate answer.

question: He  always  wants  to  be  in  the  company  of  those  who  are intellectually superior than him. SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: superior than him. There are some words that imply comparison but do not take ‘than’. Rather, ‘to’ is used with them. For example:- superior to, inferior to, prior to, senior to, junior to, elder to, etc. Hence, ‘superior to him’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I have sing ‘Let It Go’ before a crowd of thousands  of www.ssccglpinnacle.com                                                 Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Spot the Error people. SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: I have sing With ‘has/have/had’, the third form of the verb is used. However, ‘sung’ is the third form of ‘sing’. Hence, 'I have sung' is the most appropriate answer.

question: Mr Suman / asked me / to pack / my luggages. SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: my luggages. ‘Luggage’ is an uncountable noun, we cannot form its plural. Hence, ‘my luggage’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Camels  tend  to  move  slowly  than  other  domestic  animals in the plains. SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: move slowly We use comparative degree with ‘than’ to compare two persons, things or animals. The given sentence makes a comparison between the movement of camels and other domestic animals. ‘Slower’ will be used instead of ‘slowly’. Hence, ‘move slower’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Deepak  is  studying  B.tech.  at  IIT  Delhi  to  become  the engineer. SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: the engineer Indeﬁnite articles (a/an) are used when we refer to something in general. Article ‘an’ will be used here as the word ‘engineer’ begins with a vowel sound. Hence, ‘an engineer’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  following  sentence  has  been  divided  into  four segments.  Identify  the  segment  in  which  the  article  has  been used INCORRECTLY. Master Sam / is a heaviest / boy in / grade twelve. SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: is a heaviest ‘Heaviest’ is a superlative degree and we always place the deﬁnite article ‘the’ before any superlative degree. Hence, ‘is the heaviest’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Jerry driving / home late / when the incident  / took place. SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Jerry driving Helping verb is missing in this sentence. The given sentence is in the past tense, so it must have the helping ‘was’ denoting past continuous tense. Hence, ‘Jerry was driving’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  lions  became  violently  /  when  the  visitors  /  started throwing / stones at them. SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: The lions became violently ‘Became’ is a stative verb and we generally use an adjective after a stative verb. Therefore, 'violently' must be replaced with 'violent'. Hence, 'The lions became violent' is the most appropriate answer.

question: My dog / barks / very louder / at night. SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: very louder ‘Louder’ must be replaced with 'loudly'. The given sentence needs an adverb to modify the verb ‘barks’, not the adjective ‘louder’. Hence, ‘very loudly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  company  specialises  at  /  designing,  crafting  and manufacturing  /  exquisite,  high-quality  furniture  /  of  exceptional craftsmanship. SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: The company specialises at ‘At’ must be replaced with ‘in’ we use ‘in’ to talk about skill, proﬁciency or specialisation in a ﬁeld. Hence, ‘The company

question: He  and  his  friends  /  does  not  /  want  to  /  attend  the meeting. SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: does not According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a plural subject always takes a plural verb. In the given sentence, ‘He and his friends’ is a plural subject that will take ‘do’ as a plural verb. Hence, ‘do not’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  following  sentence  has  been  divided  into  four segments.  Identify  the  segment  in  which  the  article  has  been used INCORRECTLY. In  the  recent  past,  the  IT  industry  has  emerged  /  as  a  major contributor  to  an  industry  revenue  /  as  well  as  employment  / opportunity provider in the country. SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.B: In the recent past, the IT industry has emerged
options.C: as a major contributor to an industry revenue

solution.correct_answer: C. as a major contributor to an industry revenue
solution.explanation: as a major contributor to an industry revenue ‘Industry’ mentioned in the sentence is speciﬁc and we generally use the deﬁnite article ‘the’ with a speciﬁc or particular noun. Hence, ‘as a major contributor to the industry revenue’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: While  I  was  walking  to  the  store,  my  friend  calls  me  and ask for a favour. SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.B: my friend calls me and ask

options.D: Please go and meet the chairperson

solution.explanation: few next days. The order of adjectives is wrong in this phrase. The correct order would be ‘next few days’. Hence, 'next few days' is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  teacher  asked  him  not  to  keep  disturbing  the  class, but it had no affect. SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.correct_answer: A. but it had no affect.
solution.explanation: but it had no affect. ‘Affect’ must be replaced with ‘effect’ as we need a noun here to make the sentence meaningful. Hence, ‘but it had no effect’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: This is the book whom I wanted to buy. SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: whom I ‘Whom’ must be replaced with ‘which’. ‘Whom’ is used for a person whereas ‘which’ is used for things(book). Hence, ‘which I’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: My colleague always works latest than me. SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: latest We use a comparative degree with ‘than’ to make a comparison between two things. ‘Later’ is the correct comparative degree of ‘late’. Hence, ‘later’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He was / bad injured / in the / last match. SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: bad injured The given sentence needs an adverb ‘badly’ to modify the adjective ‘injured’, not the adjective ‘bad’. Hence, ‘badly injured’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: My  sister  and  I  /  work  very  hard  /  nevertheless  my brother does not do / any task assigned to him. SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.A: nevertheless my brother does not do

solution.correct_answer: A. nevertheless my brother does not do
solution.explanation: nevertheless my brother does not do ‘Nevertheless’ must be replaced with ‘but’ as we generally use ‘but’ when two statements differ from or contrast with each other. There is a contrast between working hard and not doing any task. Hence, ‘but my brother does not do’ is the most appropriate answer. SSC CHSL 2024 Tier - 1

question: The  couple  /preferred  to  walk  /  until  the  last  house  /  of the town. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: until the last house ‘Until’ must be replaced by ‘to’ because when referring to a destination or endpoint, ‘to’ is used. Hence, ‘to the last house’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Ramayana  is  an  ancient  Sanskrit  epic;  it  is  believed  to  be written around 500 BC to 100 BC. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Ramayana is an ancient The deﬁnite article 'the' is used before holy books. For example:- The Ramayana, The Mahabharata, The Quran, The Bible, etc. Hence, 'The Ramayana is an ancient' is the most appropriate answer.

question: Hard  had  she  /thrown  the  basketball  /when  it  fell  /on  the ground. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Hard had she ‘Hardly…when’ is a ﬁxed pair of conjunctions. Hence, ‘Hardly had she’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  project  was  completed  /  more  quicker  /  than expected SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: more quicker We don’t use ‘more or very’ with the comparative degree because it becomes a case of superﬂuousness (not necessary). ‘More’ will be removed from the given sentence . Hence ‘quicker’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  following  sentence  has  an  error  in  its  tense;  Identify the error and select the correct sentence from the options; If  you  had  apprised  me  about  your  problem  earlier,  I  would  have allow you to go. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.A: If you apprised me about your problem earlier, I would have
options.B: If you can apprise me about your  problem earlier, I would
options.C: If you had apprised me about your problem earlier, I would
options.D: If you had apprised me about your problem earlier, I would

solution.correct_answer: C. If you had apprised me about your problem earlier, I would
solution.explanation: If you had apprised me about your problem earlier, I would have allowed you to go. The given sentence is an example of a third conditional sentence and the correct grammatical structure for it is “If + past perfect (had + V 3 )…….. Would have + V 3 ”. Hence, ‘would have allowed (V 3 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: From  the  options given,  identify  the  sentence  that  corrects  the  error  to  make  it  a grammatically accurate sentence; Harmit is not innocent such as Uday. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.A: Harmit is not as innocent as Uday.
options.B: Harmit is not as innocent more than Uday.
options.C: Harmit is not as much as innocent as Uday.
options.D: Harmit is not innocent than Uday.

solution.correct_answer: A. Harmit is not as innocent as Uday.
solution.explanation: Harmit is not as innocent as Uday. "As...as" is a comparative structure used to compare two things. The given sentence is comparing Harmit with Uday. Hence, option (a) is the most appropriate answer.

question: When it / come to football, / my brother is  / an addict. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: come to football According to the “ Subject-Verb Agreement Rule ”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. At the end of a singular verb, s/es is used. In the given sentence, ‘it’ is a singular subject that will take ‘comes’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘comes to football’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Throw of / the old shoes; / nobody will wear  / them now. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Throw of ‘Throw off’ is the correct phrasal verb to use here. ‘Throw off’ means to rid oneself of something. The given sentence talks about getting rid of the old shoes. Hence, ‘Throw off’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: They  have  decided  /  to  wind  out  /  their  business  / without delay. SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: to wind out ‘To wind out’ must be replaced with ‘to wind up’. ‘Wind up’ means to close or conclude a business. Hence ‘to wind up’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Since  the  little  girl  answers  /  a  few  simple  questions,  / her parents say that / she is too intelligent. SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: she is too intelligent ‘Too’ must be replaced with ‘very’. ‘Too’ is used in a sentence with a negative sense. Hence ‘she is very intelligent’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: It  is  diﬃcult  to  live  in  /  the  societal  expectations  /  when one has / fewer resources. A B C D SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: A - It is diﬃcult to live in ‘Live in’ must be replaced by ‘Live up to’. ‘Live up to’ means to meet or match the expectations set by someone or something. Hence ‘It is diﬃcult to live up to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  teacher  was  /  taken  back  by  /  the  audacity  of  /  the new student. A B C D SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: B - taken back by ‘Taken back by’ must be replaced with ‘taken aback by’. The phrase ‘to be taken aback’ means to be very shocked or surprised. The given sentence states that the teacher was shocked by the audacity of the new student. Hence, ‘taken aback by’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: His  mother’s  transfer  from  a  small  town  to  Delhi  brought up a huge change in his schooling. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st Shift)

options.C: from a small town to Delhi

solution.correct_answer: A. brought up a huge change
solution.explanation: brought up a huge change ‘Brought up’ must be replaced with ‘brought about’. The phrasal verb ‘brought about’ is the past form of ‘bring about’, which means to cause something to happen. The given sentence talks about the huge change that happened due to his mother’s transfer. Hence, ‘brought about a huge change’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Mrs Meera and family / received his letter  / a week ago. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Identify  the  error  in  the  given  sentence  and  select  the correct sentence from the given options; Petriﬁed  wood  is  type  of  fossilised  wood  that  exhibits  the original details of the wood. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st Shift)

options.A: The petriﬁed wood is the type of fossilised wood that exhibits
options.B: A petriﬁed wood is type of fossilised wood that exhibits an
options.C: Petriﬁed wood is a type of fossilised wood that exhibits the
options.D: Petriﬁed wood is the type of fossilised wood that exhibits a

solution.correct_answer: C. Petriﬁed wood is a type of fossilised wood that exhibits the
solution.explanation: Petriﬁed wood is a type of fossilised wood that exhibits the original details of the wood. There is an error of article in the given sentence. The ‘type’ mentioned in the given sentence is not speciﬁc and we generally use the indeﬁnite article ‘a’ before a non-speciﬁc noun. Therefore, ‘a type of fossilied fuel’ is the corrected part. Hence, the sentence given in option (c) is the most appropriate answer.

question: (1) When  Christy/(2)  grew  out,/(3)  he  turned  out/(4)  to  be

solution.explanation: 2 - grew out ‘Grew out’ must be replaced with ‘grew up’ which means to mature or become an adult. The given sentence talks about Christy becoming an adult. Hence, ‘grew up’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The meeting / will taking / place next / Wednesday. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: will taking ‘Modal verbs’ are auxiliary verbs(also called helping verbs) like can, will, could, shall, must, would, might, and should. However, after a modal verb, we generally use the ﬁrst form of the verb (V 1 ). Hence ‘will take(V 1 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Rashmi  was  /  quite  amusing  when  /  she  heard  about  / what had happened. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: quite amusing when The given sentence needs a past participle ‘amused’ as it is in the passive voice. Rashmi was amused by what she heard. Hence, ‘quite amused when’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  following  sentence  has  been  split  into  four segments.  Identify  the  segment  that  contains  an  INCORRECT preposition. Please  remember  to  take  /  your  notice  to  the  reception  area  /  if you want it to be displayed / upon the bulletin board. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.B: if you want it to be displayed
options.C: your notice to the reception area

solution.explanation: upon the bulletin board There is a prepositional error in the sentence . ‘Upon’ must be replaced with ‘On’ . We use ‘on’ when an object is in contact with the surface of something. Similarly, the notice will be in contact with the bulletin board. Hence ‘on the bulletin board’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Today  she  said  to  her  friend,  “You’re  the  sweetest  person I have met ever”. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: I have met ever ‘Ever’ is an adverb of frequency. An adverb of frequency is generally placed before the main verb and after the helping verb. Therefore, ‘ever’ will be placed before the main verb ‘met’. Hence ‘I have ever met’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The class / teacher was / wounded in / a leg. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: a leg ‘Leg’ mentioned in the given sentence is speciﬁc and we generally use the deﬁnite article ‘the’ before any speciﬁc or particular noun. Hence, ‘in the leg’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I  had  seen  /  her  with  her  mother  /  in  the  cinema  hall  / yesterday. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: I had seen ‘Had seen’ must be replaced with 'saw'. We generally use ‘simple past tense(V 2 )’ to describe actions, events, or states that occurred and were completed in the past. Similarly, in the sentence, the action was completed yesterday. Hence, ‘I saw’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Mr. Narayanan / is a rather / lazy man. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: No error

question: My  students  are  /  waiting  for  /  their  ﬂights  /  at  the  gate no 6. SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: at the gate no.6 Use of deﬁnite article ‘the’ is incorrect. We generally do not use deﬁnite article ‘the’ when referring to speciﬁc numbered gates, rooms or sections. Hence ‘at gate no. 6’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Parts  of  the  following  sentence  have  been  underlined  and given as options. Select the option that contains an error. She  will being  studying  for her  exams tomorrow  . SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: will being ‘Will be + V-ing’ is the correct grammatical structure for the sentence which is in the future continuous tense. Hence, ‘will be’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  following  sentence  has  been  split  into  four segments  Identify  the  segment  that  contains  an  INCORRECT preposition; I  am  writing  to  invite  you  /  to  give  a  presentation  /  for  our  Jobs and Careers Conference / for engineering graduates. options.B: I am writing to invite you
options.C: for our Jobs and Careers Conference

solution.correct_answer: C. for our Jobs and Careers Conference
solution.explanation: for our Jobs and Careers Conference Preposition ‘at’ is used to indicate a speciﬁc occasion or event. Similarly, in the given sentence, ‘Jobs and Careers Conference’ is a speciﬁc event. Hence, ‘at our jobs and careers conference’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  companies  were  /  giving  in  the  prizes  /  to  attract customers / during the festive season. SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: giving in the prizes ‘Giving in’ must be replaced with ‘giving out’ . The phrasal verb ‘giving out’ means to distribute or handing over something. While ‘giving in’ means to surrender. The given sentence talks about distributing the prizes. Hence ‘giving out the prizes’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: This  artwork  /  are  a  wonderful  example  /  of  the  period's vogue / for realistic style. SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: are a wonderful example According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. In the given sentence, ‘This artwork’ is a singular subject that will take ‘is’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘is a wonderful example’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Identify the error in the following sentence  and select the option with the correct use of the phrasal verb. Prateek  was  planning  to  ask  Shreya  for  a  favour.  But  he  could not muster up the courage. So, he blacked out. SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd Shift)

The phrasal verb ‘chickened out’ means to fail to do something due to fear. While ‘blacked out’ means to lose consciousness. Hence ‘chickened out’ is the most appropriate answer.

C Stative verbs are those verbs which express a state or condition. They do not refer to a physical action. Sense and emotions like hear, smell, see, love, hate etc are different types of stative verbs. Verbs denoting thoughts and opinions include know, believe, think, understand, consider, etc. However, these verbs can’t be used in (-ing form) for example, Hear, Smell (Correct) and Hearing, Smelling (Incorrect). Hence, ‘you believe’ is the most appropriate answer.
