options.B: He wished he have more resources to support the poor.
options.C: He wishing he has more resources to support the poor.
options.D: He wished he had more resources to support the poor.

solution.correct_answer: D. He wished he had more resources to support the poor.
solution.explanation: He wished he had more resources to support the poor. The given sentence is in the simple past tense so the verb must be used in the past form(V 2 ). However, the past form of ‘has’ is ‘had’. Hence, ‘he wished he had’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Investing  on  real  estate  /  can  earn  you  quick  proﬁt  /  but  it comes with / a certain amount of risk attached to it. SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Afternoon)

options.A: a certain amount of risk attached to it

solution.explanation: Investing on real estate The preposition “on” will be replaced by “in”. Invest in is a phrasal verb which means to put money, effort, time, etc. into something to make a proﬁt or get an advantage. Hence, ‘investing in real estate’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: When  the  villagers  put  up  a  ﬁrm  resistance  to  the fearsome bandit with all their might, he ultimately ﬂeed the spot SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Evening)

options.A: When the villagers put up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome
options.B: When the villagers putted up a ﬁrm resistance to the
options.C: When the villagers put up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome
options.D: When the villagers put up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome

solution.correct_answer: D. When the villagers put up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome
solution.explanation: When the villagers put up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome bandit with all their might, he ultimately ﬂed the spot.(Correct) (a) When the villagers put up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome bandit with all their might, he ultimately ﬂew the spot.(Incorrect verb used) (b) When the villagers putted up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome bandit with all their might, he ultimately ﬂeed the spot.(Incorrect verb used) (c) When the villagers put up a ﬁrm resistance to the fearsome bandit with all their might, he ultimately ﬂown the spot.(Incorrect verb used)

question: The  General  have  ordered  that  the  troops  should  move immediately. SSC CHSL 08/06/2022 (Afternoon)

options.C: that the troops should move       (d) The General have ordered

solution.explanation: The General have ordered The general is singular so singular verb has will be used. Have is incorrect. The correct sentence will be- The General has ordered that the troops should move immediately.

question: As she kept walking to me, my heart skipped  a beat . SSC CHSL 09/06/2022 (Morning)

options.A: As she kept walking within me, my heart skipped a beat.
options.B: As she kept walking from me, my heart skipped a beat
options.C: As she kept into me, my heart skipped a beat.
options.D: As she kept walking towards me, my heart skipped a beat.

solution.correct_answer: D. As she kept walking towards me, my heart skipped a beat.
solution.explanation: As she kept walking towards me, my heart skipped a beat. (Correct) (a) As she kept walking within me, my heart skipped a beat. (Incorrect preposition) (b) As she kept walking from me, my heart skipped a beat.(Incorrect preposition) (c) As she kept into me, my heart skipped a beat.(Incorrect preposition)

question: As  soon  as  we  went  for  an  afternoon  siesta,  my  pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn. SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Morning)

options.A: As soon as we were going for an afternoon siesta, my pet
options.B: As  she  kept  walking  from  me,  my  heart  skipped  a
options.C: As  soon  as  we  gone  for  an  afternoon  siesta,  my  pet  rabbit  Tia
options.D: As  soon  as  we  gone  for  an  afternoon  siesta,  my  pet  rabbit

solution.correct_answer: B. As  she  kept  walking  from  me,  my  heart  skipped  a
solution.explanation: As soon as we went for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia dug a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Correct) (a) As soon as we were going for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Incorrect word- The past form of dig is dug) (c) As soon as we gone for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Incorrect word - The past form of dig is dug) (d) As soon as we gone for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia dug a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Incorrect verb) SSC CGL 2021 Tier - 1

question: It was / the very well-directed ﬁlm / and  we enjoyed it. SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Morning)

solution.correct_answer: A. the very well - directed ﬁlm
solution.explanation: the very well-directed ﬁlm The ‘ﬁlm’ mentioned in the given sentence is not speciﬁc and we generally use the indeﬁnite article ‘a’ before a non-speciﬁc noun. Hence, ‘a very well directed’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: If  the  economy  fails  /  this  year  it  reﬂect  badly  /  on  the government. SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Morning)

solution.correct_answer: A. this year it reﬂect badly
solution.explanation: this year it reﬂect badly The given sentence is a conditional sentence which has a futuristic sense so the verb used must be in the future tense(will). Hence, ‘it will reﬂect badly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: We stayed / in Jim’s ﬂat / during he was /  on holiday. SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Afternoon)

options.A: on holiday   (b) during he was   (c) in Jim’s ﬂat   (d) We stayed

solution.explanation: during he was ‘When’ is used for talking about the time at which something happens or happened. The given sentence talks about the time at which Jim was on holiday. Hence, ‘when he was’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  unseasonal  rain/  caused  a  lot  of  damage/  to  the crops. SSC CGL 11/04/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: No error.

question: How many / eggs were put / into the basket  ? SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)

options.A: How many (b) No error (c) eggs were put (d) into the basket

solution.explanation: No error.

question: We  have  /  not  met  /  some  of  our  friends  /  since  six months. SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: since six months ‘For’ refers to a speciﬁc period of time or a numerical value of time, for example for 2 years, for 4 weeks, for 3 days, etc. However, in the given question, the period of time is 6 months. Hence, ‘for six months’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  policeman  asked  /  many  people  but  /  no  one  was knowing / how the accident happened. SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: no one was knowing The given sentence is in the simple past tense so the verb must be used in its past form(V 2 ) and not in the past continuous form(was +V-ing). Hence, ‘no one knew(V 2 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: This question / is quite too / simple for me  / to answer. SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: is quite too The use of ‘quite’ is irrelevant in the grammatical context of the given sentence as ‘too…to’ is a ﬁxed pair. Hence, ‘is too simple for me to answer’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  manager  said,  “Could  you  please  conﬁrm  me whether you have received all the items that you had ordered?” SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: conﬁrm me whether you The use of the pronoun ‘me’ is grammatically incorrect in the given sentence so it must be removed. Hence, ‘conﬁrm whether you’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: We thought / there was a good idea / to wear  snow boots / before we stepped out. SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.correct_answer: D. there was a good idea
solution.explanation: there was a good idea ‘Idea’ in the given sentence is a singular subject and for it, we will use ‘it’ as a singular pronoun and not ‘there’. Hence, ‘it was a good idea’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: There  have  been  /three  breaks-in  /in  our  society/  this month. SSC CGL 18/04/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: three breaks-in ‘Break-in’ is a phrasal verb which means to enter a building by force, usually in order to steal something. However, the given sentence talks about three attempts so we will use the plural form of ‘break-in’. Hence, ‘three break-ins’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  Taj  Mahal  /  is  one  of  /  the  most  beautiful  /  creation in the world. SSC CGL 19/04/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: creation in the world According to the “ Subject-Verb Agreement Rule ”, ‘ One of/ Each of/ Most of/ None of + Plural Subject” is grammatically the correct structure. Similarly, the given sentence will have ‘creations’ as a plural subject. Hence, ‘creations in the world’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: This park is / the largest bird sanctuary /  in the State. SSC CGL 19/04/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: No error.

question: I  was  angry  /  on  myself  /  for  making  /  such  a  silly mistake. SSC CGL 19/04/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: on myself ‘Angry with someone’ is grammatically the correct phrase for the given sentence. Hence, ‘angry with myself’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: We bought / two dozens / mangoes from / the  market SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: two dozens We never write ‘dozens’ if we are using a numerical amount like two, three, etc. before it. For example, ‘two dozens of bananas’ is incorrect but ‘three dozen of mangoes’ is correct. Similarly, the given sentence has ‘two’ as a numerical value. Hence, ‘two dozen’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: You and I / have submitted / your work / on  time. SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Morning) www.ssccglpinnacle.com                                                 Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Spot the Error

options.A: on time  (b) your work  (c) have submitted  (d) You and I

solution.explanation: your work ‘Our’ is the possessive form of ‘we’ and it means something belonging to us(more than a single person). Similarly in the given sentence, the work belongs to both the persons and not to a single person. Hence, ‘our work’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Shall / we go / for walking / in the park? SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Afternoon)

options.A: Shall     (b) in the park     (c) we go     (d) for walking

solution.explanation: for walking When we use verbs like walk, talk, ride, drink, etc. as nouns, we put the indeﬁnite article ‘a’ before them as per their sound. For example, we had a talk, let's go for a drive, etc. Hence, ‘for a walk’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Among you and me / she is quite rude / to the  boy. SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Among you and me We use ‘among’ for more than two persons and ‘between’ for two persons. However, there are two persons mentioned in the given sentence. Hence, ‘Between you and me’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I ﬁnd that / I get myself tired / very easily  / these days. SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: I get myself tired The use of the reﬂexive pronoun ‘myself’ is irrelevant according to the grammatical context of the sentence so it will be removed. Hence, ‘I get tired’ is the most appropriate answer. SSC CGL 2020 Tier - 2

question: If  you  have  /  remained  calm  /  you  could  have  /  saved  the situation. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: If you have If you have “ If + had + V 3 …. could have + V 3 ( third form of the verb )” is the correct grammatical structure for the given sentence. Hence, ‘If you had’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I  will  spend  /  my  rest  of  remaining  /  life  in  my  /  native village. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: my rest of remaining We cannot use ‘rest’ & ‘remaining’ together in a sentence as it becomes the case of superﬂuousness(not necessary). Hence, ‘remaining’ will be removed from the sentence & ‘the rest of my life’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: This  dog  seems  /  to  be  very  ferocious,  /  otherwise,  /  it  is harmless. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022) www.ssccglpinnacle.com                                                 Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Spot the Error

solution.explanation: Otherwise ‘Otherwise‘ is a conjunction that means apart from that. However, ‘But’ is also a conjunction that is used for introducing an idea that contrasts with or is different from what has just been said. Similarly in the given sentence, the statement that the dog is harmless contrasts with its characteristic of being ferocious(violent). Hence, ‘But’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The girl lay down / on the bed / besides her  mother / and went to sleep. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: besides her mother ‘Besides’ means ‘in addition to something’ & ‘Beside’ means ‘at the side of, or next to somebody/something’. However, the given sentence states that the girl lay down on the bed next to her mother and went to sleep. Hence, ‘beside her mother’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He went / to the bed / with a / slight fever. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

options.A: slight fever         (b) to the bed         (c) with a       (d) He went

solution.explanation: to the bed We generally use the phrases ‘go to bed’, ‘gone to bed’ or ‘went to bed’. Hence, we will remove the deﬁnite article ‘the’ from the given sentence and ‘went to bed’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question: The  city  turned  out  /  to  be  very  /  different  to  what  /  he had expected. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: different to what There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘to’ after ‘different’ must be replaced with ‘from’ because ‘different’ generally takes the preposition ‘from’ with it. Hence, ‘different from what’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Your name / precedes before / mine / in the  list. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

options.A: mine  (b) Your name  (c) precedes before  (d) in the list

solution.explanation: precedes before We cannot write ‘precedes’ and ‘before’ together in a sentence as they have similar meanings & that will become a case of superﬂuousness (not necessary). Hence, ‘before’ must be removed from the sentence to make it grammatically correct.

question: You  should  /  avail  this  opportunity  /  to  demonstrate  / your skills. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: avail this opportunity ‘Avail’ always takes the preposition ‘of’ and a reﬂexive pronoun(myself, yourself, ourselves, etc.) in accordance with the given subject(You). Hence, ‘avail yourself of this opportunity’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He was unable / to help me because / he had  been failed / to arrange the money. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: he had been failed The given sentence is in the simple past tense so the verb must be used in its simple past form(failed) and not in the past perfect form(had been failed). Hence, ‘he failed’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: He  often  /  persists  to  ask  /  awkward  questions  /  at  the board meetings. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: persists to ask “ Persist + in + V-ing ” is the correct grammatical structure for the given sentence. Hence, the preposition ‘to’ must be replaced with the preposition ‘in’ and ‘persists in asking(V-ing)’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question: His  son-in-laws  /  have  enhanced  /  his  business  /  within  a short period. SSC CGL Tier II (29/01/2022)

solution.explanation: His son-in-laws We can never write ‘in-laws’ because it is incorrect to add ‘s’ in

question: Either of these / two roads / lead to / the  post oﬃce. SSC CGL Tier II (03/02/2022)

options.A: Either of these   (b) the post oﬃce   (c) lead to  (d) two roads

solution.explanation: lead to According to the “ Subject-Verb Agreement Rule ”, ‘ Either of/ Neither of + Plural Subject + Singular verb ’ is grammatically the correct structure. The given sentence has ‘Roads’ as a plural subject and ‘leads’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘leads to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: His  father  /  prevented  him  /  to  go  abroad  /  for  higher studies. SSC CGL Tier II (03/02/2022)

solution.explanation: to go abroad We generally use the preposition ‘from’ with prevent not ‘to’. Hence, we will replace ‘to’ with ‘from’ and ‘from going abroad’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question: What  is  the  name  /  of  the  Swami  /  whom  autobiography  / impressed you so much? SSC CGL Tier II (03/02/2022)

solution.explanation: whom autobiography 'Whom' is an object pronoun that refers to the person who was the recipient of an action. However, 'Whose' is a possessive pronoun that refers to the person to whom something belongs. Similarly, the given sentence refers to a Swami to whom the autobiography belongs. Hence, ‘whose autobiography’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  crowd  of  the  migrant  worker  at  the  station  for  the Shramik Special is unforgettable. SSC CGL Tier II (03/02/2022)

solution.explanation: of the migrant worker ‘Crowd’ means a large number of people in one place and these people are migrant workers(not a single worker) in the given sentence. However, it is irrelevant to use the deﬁnite article ‘the’ as the workers are not speciﬁc. Hence, ‘of migrant workers’ is the most appropriate answer. SSC MTS 2020 Tier - 1

question: Will you / listen me / when I tell you / the  details? SSC MTS 05/10/2021 (Afternoon)

options.A: Will you   (b) the details   (c) listen me   (d) when I tell you

solution.explanation: listen me There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘to’ is missing after ‘listen’. Hence, ‘listen to me’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  crow  held  back  /  to  the  piece  /  of  bread  /  with  its claws. SSC MTS 05/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: The crow held back ‘Held back’ means to not do something & ‘held on’ means to maintain a grasp on something.Both are phrasal verbs. Similarly, in the given sentence, the crow grasps the piece of bread with its claws. Hence, ‘the crow held on’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  farmer  is  /  cutting  the  corn  /  which  has  ripen  /  in  the ﬁelds. SSC MTS 06/10/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: which has ripen ‘Has + V 3 ’ is the correct grammatical structure for the given sentence. However, the V 3 form of ‘ripen’ is ‘ripened’. Hence, ‘has ripened’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Obi wanted / to continue on / his idea of /  building a modern school. SSC MTS 06/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: to continue on There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. Use the preposition ‘on’ in place of ‘with’. Hence, ‘to continue with’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: I was watching a whole scene very carefully. SSC MTS 12/10/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: a whole scene The subject ‘whole scene’ is speciﬁc & before speciﬁc or particular nouns, we use the deﬁnite article ‘the’. Hence, ‘the whole scene’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Who has distributed these sweets among the  children? SSC MTS 12/10/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Mr.  Choudhri  goes  to  ﬂy  to  Germany  and  France  next weekend. SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Mr. Choudhri goes The given sentence talks about a future action(next weekend), . The structure ‘is going to’ is generally used for future actions. Hence, ‘Mr. Choudhri is going to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Not get into the car; it has not been cleaned  inside. SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Not get The given sentence must start with a verb ‘do’ which is missing. Hence, ‘Do not get’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The  man  we  met  was  any  other  than  the  original  owner  of the house. SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: was any other The phrase ‘any other’ will be replaced with ‘different’ which means not the same person. Hence, ‘was different than’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: “You can meet me always you like,” our teacher  told us. SSC MTS 18/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: me always The word ‘always’ must be replaced with an adverb ‘anytime’ to grammatically correct the given sentence.

question: There  is  no  one  else  in  this  house;  I  can  feel  the presence. SSC MTS 22/10/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: no one else If one can feel the presence, it is obvious that there is someone present. Hence, ‘no one’ will be replaced with ‘someone’ to make the given sentence grammatically correct.

question: You look very tired; you would go to bed now. SSC MTS 22/10/2021 (Morning)

options.A: You look   (b) to bed now   (c) you would go   (d) very tired

solution.explanation: you would go There is a modal verb error in the given sentence. The modal verb ‘would’ must be replaced with ‘should’ as the sentence is showing a sense of suggestion. Hence, ‘you should go’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: The little baby cried loudly to a new toy. SSC MTS 22/10/2021 (Evening)

options.B: to a   (c) new toy   (d) The little baby

solution.correct_answer: B. to a   (c) new toy   (d) The little baby
solution.explanation: to a ‘Cry for something’ is a phrase that means to express a want or need through crying. Similarly in the given sentence, the child is expressing his need for the toy through crying. Hence, ‘for a toy’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: This  is  the  place  here  Sudhir  found  the  wallet  full  of money. SSC MTS 26/10/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: here Sudhir ‘Where’ means in or to what place or position. The given sentence talks about a place where Sudhir found the wallet full of money. Hence, ‘where’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Although  we  took  all  precautions  but  we  were  unable  to avoid getting caught in the heavy rain. SSC MTS 26/10/2021 (Afternoon)

options.B: Although we took all precautions but

solution.correct_answer: B. Although we took all precautions but
solution.explanation: Although we took all precautions but The ‘precautions’ mentioned in the given sentence are speciﬁc & we use the deﬁnite article ‘the’ before speciﬁc or particular nouns. We need not use the conjunction “but” as the word “although’ at the beginning of the sentence shows the contrast. Hence, ‘Although we took all the precautions ’ is the most appropriate answer. Correct sentence- Although we took all the precautions we were unable to avoid getting caught in the heavy rain.

question: I’m  sure  that  I  found  the  place  without  any  diﬃculty  when I go next time. SSC MTS 26/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: I found the place The given sentence shows an action of future tense(next time) so the verb must be used in its future form(will) and not in the past form(found). Hence, ‘I will ﬁnd the place’ is the most appropriate answer.

question: Asking  for  and  giving  informations  is  an  important feature of conversations. SSC MTS 27/10/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: giving informations Some Nouns like Cattle, work, Information, Scenery, Furniture , etc. are always written in the singular form so we can't make their plural form. For example, ‘furniture’ is correct but ‘furnitures’ is incorrect. Similarly in the given sentence, ‘informations’ will be replaced with ‘information’.

question: Every country tries to do its good at the Olympic  games as they are held in great prestige. SSC MTS 02/11/2021 (Morning)

options.A: they are held  (b) Every country  (c) its good  (d) tries to do

solution.explanation: its good Replace “its good” by “well”. Good' is an adjective like a good boy, a good book, etc & 'Well' is an adverb like, He performed well. Similarly, in the given sentence, we need an adverb to modify the verb 'do'. Hence, 'well' is the most appropriate answer.

question: Judy  solved  the  diﬃcult  problem  by  her  own  without anyone’s help. SSC MTS 02/11/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: by her own There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘by’ must be replaced with ‘on’. Hence, ‘on her own’ is the most appropriate structure. “On her own” means by herself and unaided. SSC CGL 2020 Tier - 1

question: You  must  avoid  riding  in  a  crowded  bus  /  or  travelling  in  a metro  /  during  rush  hour  /  as  both  are  quiet  unpleasant experiences. SSC CGL 13/08/2021 (Morning)

options.A: You must avoid riding in a crowded bus
options.C: as both are quiet unpleasant experiences

solution.correct_answer: C. as both are quiet unpleasant experiences
solution.explanation: as both are quiet unpleasant experiences Quiet is an adjective that means with very little or no noise & ‘Quite’ is an adverb that is used for emphasizing something. However, the given sentence does not talk about any sound or noise. Hence, ‘both are quite unpleasant experiences’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Won’t  you  /  please  come  /  to  help  me  /  along  this  heavy box? SSC  CGL 17/08/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: along this heavy box The phrase “Would/Will/Can you help me with this______” is grammatically the correct structure that we use when we ask someone for help in doing something. Similarly, in the given sentence, the narrator is asking someone to help him/her lift a heavy bag. Hence, ‘with this heavy box’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: The  construction  of  the  new  business  school  is  led  to  a sudden rise of population in our area. SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Afternoon) www.ssccglpinnacle.com                                                 Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Spot the Error

options.A: a sudden rise of population in our area

solution.explanation: is led to The given sentence is in the present perfect tense so the verb must be used in its present perfect form(has) and not in the present/base form(is). Hence, ‘has led to’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: When she went for a walk / Maya couldn't take  off her scarf / because it was / too much windy. SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Evening)

options.B: Maya couldn't take off her scarf
options.D: When she went for a walk

solution.explanation: too much windy We use "too much" before uncountable nouns like too much money(uncountable), too much milk, etc. However, "too many" is used before countable nouns like too many shoes(countable), too many books, etc. But, in the given sentence, ‘windy’ is not a noun it is an adjective. So, we will remove ‘much’ before ‘windy’. Hence, either ‘too windy’ or ‘too much wind(noun)’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: We  don't  really  /  want  a  large  house;  /  we  are  looking  for some comfort / and some convenience on a moderate price. SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Morning)

options.A: and some convenience on a moderate price
options.D: we are looking for some comfort

solution.correct_answer: A. and some convenience on a moderate price
solution.explanation: and some convenience on a moderate price There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘on’ will be replaced with ‘at’ because we generally buy something at a low/high price, not on a low/high price. Hence, ‘some convenience at a moderate price’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Lalitha will go / to sister’s house / in Mumbai  / this summer. SSC CGL18/08/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: to sister’s house There is a pronoun error in the given sentence. The possessive pronoun ‘her’ that is generally used for a female subject(Lalitha in the given sentence) is missing. Hence, ‘to her sister’s house’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Several  prominent  ﬁlm  stars  /  have  appeared  on television / on behalf of awareness / about hand hygiene. SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: on behalf of awareness The phrase ‘on behalf of the’ means as a representative of someone or something. However, in the given sentence, article ‘the’ is missing from the phrase. Hence, ‘on behalf of the awareness’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: The  concept  became  /  too  much  clear  to  me  /  after  my tutor / showed me the diagram. SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.correct_answer: A. too much clear to me
solution.explanation: too much clear to me The use of the phrase ‘too much’ is not necessary for the sentence because it is used before uncountable nouns like too much money and ‘clear’ is not a noun. Hence, ‘became clearer to me’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: The  balloon  ﬂew  up  /  as  soon  as  /  the  man  cutting  the string. SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Evening)

solution.correct_answer: B. the man cutting the string
solution.explanation: the man cutting the string The given sentence is in the past tense(ﬂew) so the verb must be used in its simple past form(cut) and not in the present continuous form(cutting). Hence, ‘the man cut the string ’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Mithila  art  tradition  is  passed  on  /  from  one  generation through  a  next  /  by  children  watching  and  helping  /  their  mothers and grandmothers. SSC CGL 24/08/2021 (Evening)

options.A: from one generation through a next
options.B: Mithila art tradition is passed on

solution.correct_answer: A. from one generation through a next
solution.explanation: from one generation through a next There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘through’ must be replaced with ‘to’. Hence, ‘from one generation to the next’ is the most appropriate structure. SSC CHSL 2020 Tier - 1

question: Electric  heaters  were  providing  to  all  the  oﬃcers  at  the guest house. SSC CHSL 12/04/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: were providing The given sentence is in the passive voice so the verb must be used in its past form(provided) and not in the continuous form(providing). Hence, ‘were provided’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Einstein’s  school  teachers  thought  he  would  never success in life. SSC CHSL 12/04/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: never success Succeed is a verb that means to manage to achieve what you want. But, success is a noun. However, the given sentence needs a verb. Hence, ‘never succeed’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: That man would have attacked you, if you went  that way. SSC CHSL 13/04/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: if you went “If + sub + Had + V 3 …….would have + V 3 ” is grammatically the correct structure for the given sentence. Hence, ‘If you had gone’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: The  government  has  announced  a  gradual  reboot  of  air travel who was halted two months ago due to lockdown. SSC CHSL 16/04/2021 (Morning)

options.C: The government has announced      (d) who was halted

solution.explanation: who was halted Replace “who” with “which”. In the given sentence, the halting of air travel due to lockdown was speciﬁc. Hence, ‘which was halted’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Keep  looking,  and  /  you  are  sure  to  ﬁnd  the  meaning  /  of the word on that page. SSC CHSL 16/04/2021 (Afternoon)

options.A: of the word on that page  (b) you are sure to ﬁnd the meaning

solution.explanation: No error. The sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Most  hotels  /  offer  for  their  guests  /  complimentary breakfast / during their stay there. SSC CHSL 16/04/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: offer for their guests There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The use of ‘for’ after ‘offer’ is irrelevant so it should be removed. Hence, ‘most hotels offer their guests complimentary breakfast’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: I'm sorry, sir. / How many is / the ﬁne for  / returning the books late? SSC CHSL 19/04/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: How many is ‘Many’ is used for countable nouns, for example how many apples. However, ‘much’ is used for uncountable nouns for example how much money, how much rice, etc. Similarly in the given sentence, ﬁne is uncountable. Hence, ‘how much is the ﬁne for?’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: At  the  workshop,  /  they  were  taught  how  to  nail  /  the pieces of wood together to create toys. SSC CHSL 04/08/2021 (Evening)

options.B: they were taught how to nail
options.C: the pieces of wood together to create toys

solution.explanation: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question: A  probe  has  been  ordered  /  by  the  incident  /  that occurred at the celebrations. SSC CHSL 05/08/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: by the incident ‘Probe into’ a correct phrase meaning(To begin inquiring into or investigating something). The correct sentence will be as follows: A probe has been ordered into the incident that occurred at the celebrations.

question: If  you  rent  a  house  near  your  oﬃce,  it  will  save  you  time as well as also money. SSC CHSL 06/08/2021 (Morning)

solution.correct_answer: B. as well as also money
solution.explanation: as well as also money ‘As well as’ is a conjunction that means in addition. It connects two nouns, pronouns etc. to each other. So, use only ‘money’ in place of ‘also money’.The conjunction 'as well as' is not immediately followed by ' also'.Hence the correct sentence will be as : If you rent a house near your oﬃce, it will save you time as well as money.

question: Notwithstanding  we  were  /  all  busy  that  weekend  /  we had to / cancel the outing. SSC CHSL 06/08/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Notwithstanding we were “Notwithstanding” means “despite or in spite of something” . It is used to indicate an aspect of contrast. So, ‘Notwithstanding’ will be replaced by ‘as’ to make the sentence grammatically correct.

question: Every  participant  gave  so  outstanding  performance  that it became diﬃcult to choose the winner. SSC CHSL 06/08/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: so outstanding performance Such is used for emphasizing the degree of something. The given sentence tells about a performance of outstanding degree. Hence, ‘so outstanding performance’ will be replaced by ‘such an outstanding performance’ to grammatically correct the given sentence.

question: The  need  today  is  for  both  sides  /  to  introspect  and re-examine the issue carefully / and resolve it amicably. SSC CHSL 09/08/2021 (Morning)

options.A: to introspect and re-examine the issue carefully
options.D: The need today is for both sides

solution.explanation: No error . The sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Only  ﬁve  minutes  /  are  allowed  /  for  each  speaker  / during the function. SSC CHSL 11/08/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: are allowed The compound nouns (numerical + noun) are not used as the plural if a noun does the work as an adjective. Here replace ‘are’ with ‘is’ to make the sentence grammatically correct. SSC CPO 2019 Tier - 2

question: You need to sign / these important documents  / by ink. SSC CPO Tier II (26/07/2021)

solution.explanation: by ink There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘by’ must be replaced with ‘in’ because we generally write ‘in ink’ for example ﬁll the form in blue ink, sign the cheque in ink, etc. Similarly, in the given sentence, the documents need to be signed in ink. Hence, ‘in ink’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: She speaks / very highly / of both her / daughter-in-laws. SSC CPO Tier II (26/07/2021)

solution.explanation: daughter-in-laws We can never write ‘-in-laws’ because adding ‘s’ in the suﬃx(in-law) is wrong. However, we write daughter-in-law for a single female and daughters-in-law for more than two females. Similarly, the given sentence talks about two daughters-in-law. Hence, ‘daughters-in-law’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: His loyalty / and honesty / are above / suspect. SSC CPO Tier II (26/07/2021)

options.A: suspect     (b) and honesty     (c) His loyalty     (d) are above

solution.correct_answer: A. suspect     (b) and honesty     (c) His loyalty     (d) are above
solution.explanation: suspect The phrase ‘ above suspicion ’ is used to describe someone who would never be suspected of doing anything wrong. Similarly, the given sentence states that his honesty and loyalty are above suspicion. Hence, ‘suspicion’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: Parul is / ten years / elder than / her sibling. SSC CPO Tier II (26/07/2021)

options.A: elder than    (b) Parul is    (c) her sibling    (d) ten years

solution.correct_answer: A. elder than    (b) Parul is    (c) her sibling    (d) ten years
solution.explanation: elder than The comparative degree ‘elder’ will not be used with ‘than’ because it will become a case of superﬂuousness(not necessary). Hence, ‘than’ will be replaced with ‘to’ and ‘elder to’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: He is / afraid from / all insects / that crawl. SSC CPO Tier II (26/07/2021)

options.A: He is  (b) that crawl    (c) all insects    (d) afraid from

solution.explanation: afraid from Afraid generally takes the preposition ‘of’ and not ‘from’. Hence, ‘afraid of’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: He wanted to know / the reason / why his low  score / in Mathematics. SSC CPO Tier II (26/07/2021)

solution.explanation: why his low score If an Interrogative sentenc e(in which a question is asked) is written in the Indirect form(speech) , then “ Wh-word(why, when, where ) + Subject + Verb ” is grammatically the correct structure for it. Hence, ‘why his(subject) score was(verb) low’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: This is / only mistake / he has made / in the  dictation. SSC CPO Tier II (26/07/2021)

options.A: only mistake (b) in the dictation (c) he has made (d) This is

solution.correct_answer: A. only mistake (b) in the dictation (c) he has made (d) This is
solution.explanation: only mistake The article ‘the’ is used to refer to speciﬁc or particular nouns & articles ‘a/an’ are used to modify non-speciﬁc or non-particular nouns. For example, if someone says, "Let's buy the book," it means a speciﬁc book but if someone says, "Let's buy a book," it means any book rather than a speciﬁc book. Similarly, the given sentence talks about a speciﬁc mistake. Hence, ‘the only mistake’ is the most appropriate structure. SSC CPO 2020 Tier - 1

question: I am hearing a strange noise now. SSC CPO 23/11/2020 (Morning)

options.A: noise now     (b) a strange     (c) No error    (d) I am hearing

solution.explanation: I am hearing Stative verbs are those verbs which express a state of condition. They do not refer to a physical action. Sense and emotions like hear, smell, see, love, hate etc are different types of stative verbs. However, these verbs can’t be used in (-ing form) for example, Hear, Smell(Correct) and Hearing, Smelling(Incorrect). Hence, ‘I hear a strange noise’ will be the answer.

question: All  of  us  were  a  little  nervous  when  we  came  into  this room today. SSC CPO  23/11/2020 (Morning)

options.C: when we came into this room today  (d) All of us were

solution.explanation: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question: Do you earn so much to make both ends meet? SSC CPO 23/11/2020 (Evening)

options.A: make both  (b) so much to  (c) ends meet  (d) Do you earn

solution.explanation: so much to The phrase ‘so much’ is used to mention a deﬁnite unknown quantity and ‘much’ is used with uncountable nouns. However, when we ask about someone’s earning, we usually ask how much you earn and not how ‘so much’ you earn. Hence, ‘Do you earn much’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question: You  cannot  lead  a  healthy  life  although  you  stop smoking. SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Morning)

solution.explanation: although you It is a conditional sentence which has two conditions and starts with a negative sense(cannot). It says one cannot lead a healthy life, one does not quit smoking. Unless is a negative conditional conjunction which means ‘If___not’ and it is used to combine these two conditions. Hence, Unless will replace although.

question: I  had  to  hold  on  to  the  wall  to  steady  itself  or  I  could  have fallen. SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Morning)

solution.explanation: to steady itself According to the context of the sentence, the reﬂexive pronoun ‘myself’ will replace ‘itself’ because the subject(noun)/the narrator is a human being and for living things we use ‘myself’. Hence, ‘to steady myself’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question: The jury are from different parts of the country. SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Evening)

options.A: different parts   (b) are from   (c) of the country    (d) The jury

solution.explanation: are from Jury/Team/Committee are considered as a singular subject and will take a singular verb, until they are divided in their opinion/views. For example, the Jury(Singular subject) has given its decision(United) , the committee(Plural subject) are divided in their opinion(Divided). Similarly in the given question, ‘the jury is(singular verb) from different parts of the country’ is the most appropriate structure.

question: She picked up the books lie on the table and put them on the shelf. SSC CPO 25/11/2020 (Morning)

solution.explanation: lie on the table Lying is a non-ﬁnite verb which is acting as an adjective for the books in the given sentence. Hence, ‘Books lying on the table’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question: He is over eighty and dare not read without  glasses. SSC CPO 25/11/2020 (Evening)

solution.explanation: dare not read Dare means to challenge someone for something. According to the context of the sentence, we have to show the inability of the person to see and for ability/inability, we will use ‘can’ and not dare. Hence, ‘cannot read’ will be the correct sentence structure.
